conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions committee—I'm Student_B and I’m applying because School_B is my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would commit to enrolling if offered the seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_B. Although School_B ranks me 3rd (behind Student_D and Student_A), applying immediately gives me the best chance to secure my first choice before higher-priority students potentially take the only seat. I will make a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and willingness to enroll.

conversation.message: Dear Student_B, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_B is your first choice. After reviewing applications this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest in School_B and wish you the very best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_B is #3 on School_B’s true priority list (behind Student_D and Student_A). In round 1, only Student_B has applied. However, Student_D and Student_A both rank School_B as their 3rd and 4th choice respectively, so they may apply later if rejected elsewhere. With quota 1, accepting Student_B now could block a higher-priority match. Since we can reject and keep the seat open, and there is a reasonable chance higher-priority students may become available in subsequent rounds, it is optimal to reject Student_B at this time to preserve capacity for Student_D/Student_A.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_C and I’m applying because School_D is my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would gladly accept an offer if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D. I have relatively strong priority there (School_D ranks me 3rd), so applying immediately gives me a real chance to secure my first choice before the seat is taken by higher-priority applicants (Student_D and Student_E).

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_D.

Congratulations—we look forward to welcoming you to our community.

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_C is #3 on School_D’s true priority list (behind Student_D and Student_E). In round 1, only Student_C has applied to us. However, Student_D is our top priority and is unlikely to apply to School_D soon because School_D is last on Student_D’s preference list; Student_E ranks School_D 4th, so also not very likely to apply early. Since we have quota 1 and an [ACCEPT] creates an immediate binding match that removes us from the market, rejecting now risks ending unmatched or being forced to take a lower-priority student later. Given Student_C has School_D as first choice and is a high-priority candidate for us, accepting secures a strong match with relatively low opportunity cost.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m formally applying because School_C is my first choice. I’m especially drawn to your academic environment and would be highly committed to enrolling if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, so I should apply immediately. Although School_C ranks me 4th, early application is still my best chance to secure my highest true preference before other higher-priority students fill the single seat.

conversation.message:

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: School_C has quota 1 and true priority ranks Student_D (3rd) above Student_E (4th). In round 1, both D and E applied. Since accepting E now would fill the only seat and block a higher-priority candidate (D) who is already applying and states School_C is first choice, the optimal move is to reject E to preserve the seat for D. E may still match elsewhere (also has School_B as 2nd), while D is a stronger fit for School_C's priority ordering.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions—I'm Student_D and I’m formally applying. School_C is my first-choice school because I value a rigorous academic environment and I believe I can contribute strongly to the community. If admitted, I will accept and enroll. conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd), and applying immediately maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before others commit elsewhere. Even if other strong candidates apply, an early formal application is my best move given the one-seat quota.

conversation.message:

conversation.thought: School_C true priority: C > B > D > E > A. Current applicants to School_C this round: D and E. Between them, D is ranked higher than E, so accepting D is better than accepting E. However, D is only 3rd on our list; we would prefer Student_C or Student_B if attainable. Check likelihood: Student_C ranks School_C 4th (behind D, A, B) so unlikely to apply early; Student_B ranks School_C last, very unlikely. If we reject D now, we may end up unmatched or forced later to take a lower-ranked student. Since quota is 1 and we can secure a relatively high-priority candidate who also states School_C is first choice (high commitment), accepting now is the safest strategy to maximize expected outcome.

conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched. School_E is on my true preference list (ranked 5th), and I prefer matching to being unmatched. Since this is likely my last available option, I should submit a clear [APPLY] expressing strong commitment to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_E. After reviewing your request in the context of our current admissions priorities and limited capacity, we are not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate the time and effort you put into your application, and we wish you the very best in the remainder of the process.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). With quota 1 and no current match, accepting now would lock in a relatively low-priority student and foreclose the chance to match with higher-priority students (Student_A/Student_C/Student_B) who may still be unmatched or may apply later if rejected elsewhere. Since we can reject and remain available, and we prefer leaving the seat unfilled over a worse outcome than our priority list (all students are included, but ranking matters), the strategic choice is to reject Student_E to preserve capacity for higher-ranked candidates.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

I’m Student_E. I understand I was not offered admission earlier, but since School_E still has an open seat and we are late in the process, I’d like to respectfully re-submit my formal application.

If admitted now, I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling at School_E. I’m looking for a stable academic community where I can contribute consistently, and I’m ready to finalize my placement without delay.

Thank you for reconsidering my application.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though last). I have already applied once and was rejected, but since it is the only remaining option, I should re-apply with a clear, credible commitment to enroll immediately if accepted and a concise appeal that I will be a reliable, low-risk admit given the late stage and their unfilled seat.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

We appreciate your patience and effort, and we wish you the best in securing a placement for the remainder of the process.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority list ranks Student_E 4th (A, C, B, E, D). I currently have 1 open seat, but accepting Student_E now would prevent me from potentially matching later with higher-priority students (Student_A/Student_C/Student_B) if they become unmatched and apply to me in later rounds. Given the market, those higher-priority students currently rank School_E last, so they are unlikely to apply soon, but it is still possible if they are rejected elsewhere late in the process. Since Student_E is on my list but not near the top, and I already rejected them once, the optimal strategy to maximize my chance of a higher-priority match is to continue to hold the seat and reject for now rather than lock in a lower-ranked match.

conversation.message:

I’m looking to finalize my placement and would be grateful for the opportunity to join and contribute reliably to the School_E community.

Thank you for your reconsideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched, and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). I have already applied twice and been rejected, but with an open seat late in the process, a final attempt is worthwhile. I will apply again, emphasizing immediate commitment and flexibility, while keeping the message concise and respectful given prior rejections.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E and for your clear commitment to enroll if admitted. We have reviewed your application again, and we are pleased to offer you admission to School_E.

Please confirm your acceptance so we can finalize your placement.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority order is A > C > B > E > D, and I have 1 seat. Student_E is 4th on my list, so I should only accept them if it is unlikely that Student_A/Student_C/Student_B will become available to me later. Given students’ preferences, Student_A ranks School_E last, Student_C ranks School_E last, and Student_B ranks School_E 4th; all three are much more likely to match with higher-ranked schools they prefer before ever coming to School_E. By round 5, the probability that A/C/B will apply to me is low, while Student_E is actively applying and willing to commit immediately. Holding the seat risks ending unmatched. Therefore, accepting Student_E now best secures a match while still staying within my acceptable list.
